content: The FDA, or U.S. Food and Drug Administration, is responsible for regulating and ensuring the safety and efficacy of food and drugs in the United States. The FDA reviews new drugs and medical devices before they are made available to the public, and oversees the testing and production of these products. The agency also monitors the safety of food products and regulates the labeling and marketing of all products sold in the country. The FDA is also responsible for identifying and addressing potential safety concerns, issuing recalls, and taking enforcement actions against companies that violate regulations. Overall, the FDA plays a critical role in protecting the public health by ensuring the safety of food and drug products that Americans rely on every day.
